oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cumberland Gap: The Church of the Living God
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of The Church of the Living God (formerly Cumberland Gap Methodist Church), circa 1905, Gothic Revivial influence one-story frame structure; gable roof; flanking square tower with double leaf entrance with multi-light arched transom, arched ventilation openings with wooden slats, multi-light stained glass windows in Gothic arches; cement stairs lead up to doors from a side walk

The Cumberland Gap Historic District is significant for the patterns of Claiborne County's history as a a late nineteenth and early twentieth century mining town, fueled by English capitalists, and an example of late nineteenth town architecture in Claiborne County. For over two hundred years, Cumberland Gap has served as a significant passageway to the lands west of the Appalachian mountains.
